I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
of  CNY600  million  (or  its  equivalent  in  US  dollars)  to  the  Longjiang  Environmental  Protection 
Group Share Company Limited (LJEP) for the Songhua River Basin Water Pollution Control and 
Management Project Private Sector Facility, Phase 2 in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

The project is the second phase of the Songhua River Basin Water Pollution Control and 
2. 
Management  Project  Private  Sector  Facility,1 which  is  part  of  a  broader  multiproject  initiative 
under  the  East  Asia  Department  and  the  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank (ADB)  to  address  acute  water  stress  in  the  Songhua  River  basin  (SRB) of 
northeastern PRC.2  
 
3. 
Approved on 16 April 2010, phase 1 assists LJEP through (i) an equity investment of the 
lesser  of  $10  million  or  15%  of  total  paid-up  equity  capital,  (ii)  an  A-loan  of  up  to  CNY250 
million,  and  (iii)  a  B-loan  of  up  to  $100  million.3 Phase  1  supports  LJEP’s  investment  plan  to 
build,  acquire,  upgrade,  and/or  expand,  and  then  operate  wastewater  treatment  plants 
(WWTPs) and water supply utilities. Equity and A-loan funds are fully disbursed and performing, 
but the B-loan has been delayed by conditions in international financial markets.4   

2. 

Project Design 

4. 
The  project  builds  on  the  success  of  phase  1  by  supporting  LJEP  in  broadening  its 
investment  plan.  The  project  is  thus  conceived  as  parallel  assistance  to  LJEP  that  avoids 
overlap with phase 1.  
 
5. 
Sludge management. The PRC faces intensifying environmental and public health risks 
from untreated sludge, the waste byproduct of sewage treatment.  Despite the country’s recent 
progress in expanding wastewater treatment, capacity for sludge treatment, disposal, and reuse 
remains severely underdeveloped.5 Most wastewater operators simply thicken sludge, minimally 
dewatering  it  before  disposing  of  it  in  landfills.  The  resulting  waste,  high  in  water  content, 
occupies  scarce  landfill  capacity,  contaminates  groundwater  and  land,  and  emits  greenhouse 
gases  without  control.  The  Government  of  the  PRC  has  identified  sludge  management  as  an 
urgent development need and is promoting investments in treatment and disposal. The Twelfth

Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015  introduces  the  concept  of  technical  routes  for  sludge  treatment, 
promotes low-carbon approaches to sludge management, and sets the national goal of treating 
80% of sludge in large cities and 70% in small cities by 2015.6 Together, these policies establish 
new  national  standards  for  sludge  treatment  and  mandate  local  government  implementation. 
The  12th  plan  also  envisions  10%  of  the  CNY380  billion  budgeted  for  the  wastewater  sector 
being used to address sludge. The government will soon require all new WWTPs to incorporate 
sludge treatment capability and will regulate treatment levels according to plant size.7 
 
Wastewater  treatment  plant  effluent  emissions  standards.  In  addition  to  volume 
6. 
targets for wastewater treatment, a feature of past  plans, the 12th plan calls for raising quality 
standards. It states that by 2015, the PRC will reduce effluent chemical oxygen demand by 8% 
from  2010  levels,  nitrate  emissions  by  10%,  and  ammonia  nitrogen  emissions  by  10%. 
Accordingly, tighter effluent emission standards are being phased in for all WWTPs, subject to 
plant  technology  and  location.  To  induce  upgrades,  the  government  has  implemented  higher 
tariffs for WWTPs meeting higher standards. 
 
Songhua River basin. The SRB is the third largest river basin in the PRC, after those of 
7. 
the Yangtze and Yellow  rivers,  with an area of 557,000 square kilometers and a population of 
62 million.8 The SRB is acknowledged by the government as one of the five most polluted river 
basins  in  the  country.  Known  and  suspected  contaminants  include  a  number  of  trace  organic 
chemicals and metals, as well as conventional pollutants. Significant portions of the river have 
quality categorizations of class IV or V, meaning the water is unsuitable for municipal domestic 
use. In response, the government has made improved water quality and responsible utilization 
priorities  in  the  SRB’s  plan,  targeting  class  III  water  quality  for  the  entire  basin  by  2020.  ADB 
has  supported  these  goals  through  multiple  loan  and  technical  assistance  projects  with 
provincial governments in the SRB. 

3. 

The Borrower and/or Sponsor 

8. 
LJEP, the borrower, is the leading provider of wastewater treatment and related services 
in Heilongjiang. The company was founded in 2004 under the original name Tongfang (Harbin) 
Water Engineering.  
 
9. 
LJEP’s  business  model  is  to  operate  WWTPs,  water  supply  systems,  and  related 
infrastructure in the SRB. Projects are typically public–private partnerships under build-operate-
transfer  or  transfer-operate-transfer  concessions.  LJEP  operates  15 WWTPs  with  a  combined 
processing  capacity  of  1.97  million  t/d  and  two  municipal  water  utilities  with  680,000  t/d  of 
treatment and delivery capacity.  

B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

10. 
Impacts.  The  project  has  two  related  impacts.  First,  the  project  will  contribute  to 
improved water quality and public health for urban residents in the SRB. Upgrading WWTPs will 
directly  support  the  government’s  policy  of  tightening  environmental  standards  for  urban 
wastewater,  improving  water  quality,  and reducing  public  health  risks.  Second,  the  project  will

investment program in Heilongjiang for treating and disposing of sludge, the project will serve as 
a model for future sludge projects in the water-short northern PRC. The approach of scaling up 
a  high-performing  private  sector  firm,  while  cofinancing  with  international  banks  through 
unfunded  risk  participation  (URP),  has  strong  demonstration  effects  for  private  sector 
investment in PRC urban infrastructure and potential for replication in other developing member 
countries of ADB.  
 
Outcome.  The  investment  will  improve  sludge  and  wastewater  management  in  project 
11. 
counties in Heilongjiang. Capacity to treat effluents to a higher standard will be improved, as will 
capacity  to  safely  treat  sludge.  The  project  will  not  only  improve  sludge  treatment,  but  the 
conversion of sludge into fertilizer for urban landscaping will underscore the viability of  reusing 
sludge as a resource. 
 
12. 
Output.  The  project  will  expand  capacity  for  wastewater  and  sludge  treatment.  Other 
socioeconomic benefits from the investment, captured in the design and monitoring framework, 
include  job  creation  at  WWTPs  and  sludge  facilities  and  spending  on  local  goods  and 
services.10 Municipalities  covered  by  the  project  will  benefit  from  a  package  of  unquantified 
benefits that includes improved environmental services, capital investment, and technology and 
managerial expertise. 

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

13. 
Consistency with Strategy 2020. The project supports two of the five core operational 
areas of Strategy 2020: infrastructure and environment.11 Regarding infrastructure, the project is 
consistent with the strategy’s urban infrastructure focus on water supply, sanitation, and waste, 
as  well  as  with  its  emphasis  on  public–private  partnership  and  private  sector  engagement. 
Regarding the environment, the project mitigates water pollution and health threats arising from 
urbanization and economic growth. 

14. 
Consistency with country strategy. By supporting inclusive growth and environmental 
sustainability,  the  project  directly  addresses  two  of  the  three  development  goals  of  the  PRC 
country  partnership  strategy  and  aligns  with  the  country  partnership  strategy’s  affirmation  of 
natural  resource  and  urban  development  as  priority  sectors.12 It  strongly  complements  ADB’s 
current  initiatives  in  water  pollution  control  and  wastewater  treatment  in  the  PRC. The  project 
will be the fifth component of a comprehensive and integrated river basin management strategy, 
initiated  in  2002,  which  includes  private  and  public  sector  operations  to  improve  the 
management  of  water  supply,  wastewater,  and  solid  wastes  in  the  SRB.13 It  builds  on  ADB’s

15. 
Consistency with ADB sector strategy and operations. The project is an example of 
the  type  of  intervention  envisaged  by  ADB's  Water  Financing  Program,  2011–2020,  which 
promotes  water  as  a  core  investment  area  and  raises  ADB’s  water  investment  target  to  $2.5 
billion a year, or $25 billion by 2020.15 It aligns with ADB's Water Policy, which recognizes that 
remedies to water stress must include reversing the degradation of water resources caused by 
agricultural,  industrial,  and  municipal  effluents.16 Similarly,  the  Water  Operational  Plan,  2011–
2020  identifies  wastewater  management  and  reuse  as  a  key  operational  focus  in  rapidly 
industrializing countries like the PRC.17

A. 

The Assistance 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

17. 
ADB’s  proposed  assistance  is  a  loan  of  up  to  CNY600  million  (or  its  equivalent  in  US 
dollars). It will carry an interest rate, commitment and front-end fees, and URP fees approved by 
ADB’s  investment  committee.  ADB  will  enter  into  an  URP  agreement  with  eligible  commercial 
banks for at least CNY300 million (or its equivalent in US dollars) of the commitment.  
 
LJEP  will  act  as  borrower  and  direct  ADB  funds  to  subprojects  in  several  cities. 
18. 
Subprojects  will  be  held  either  directly  through  LJEP  or  through  special-purpose  subsidiaries. 
Repayment will rely primarily on the cash flows from LJEP’s portfolio of both new and existing 
subprojects.  

B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

Project 

19. 
Catalyzing  private  sector  participation.  The  project  provides  a  pioneering  private 
sector wastewater operator with access to needed finance, which is difficult to obtain from local 
banks  because  of  their  relative  inexperience  in  the  sector  and  perceptions  that  private  sector 
borrowers  are  riskier,  or  from  international  banks  because  of  volatility  in  financial  markets.  In 
addition, the URP mobilizes cofinancing in an area  with little international bank participation to 
date.  
  
20. 
innovation.  The  project  combines  several  features  innovative  in  PRC 
infrastructure finance. It is structured as a multiproject loan facility, in effect bundling small- and 
medium-sized  subprojects  to  avoid  the  high  transaction  costs  associated  with  stand-alone 
project financing and to diversify risk. In addition, ADB’s loan will be provided in local currency, 
using renminbi sourced from ADB’s renminbi-denominated bond proceeds. 
 
Demonstration  effects.  Through  partnership  with  a  highly  competent  operator,  the 
21. 
project will demonstrate how sludge and WWTP upgrade investments can be commercially and 
technically viable. Further, ADB’s requirements will ensure that LJEP operates according to best 
international  practices  and  adheres 
to  high  standards  of  corporate  governance  and 
environmental  and  social  protection,  serving  as  a  model  for  the  industry.  Finally,  ADB’s 
experience  with  the  project  can  meaningfully  contribute  to  the  dialogue  on  wastewater  sector 
management and regulation in the PRC and the region. 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is category B 
33. 
for  environment.  LJEP  has  established  an  environmental  and  social  management  system 
(ESMS) under phase 1. For phase 2, a corporate audit of LJEP’s performance in implementing 
its  ESMS  was undertaken  by  independent  consultants. The  audit found the  ESMS  adequately 

 6 

  

requirements  and  LJEP’s  environmental 
addressing  ADB’s  environmental  safeguard 
performance  satisfactory.  LJEP  undertakes  extensive  and  real-time  environmental  monitoring, 
monthly  reporting,  and  annual  performance  audits.  To  date,  LJEP  has  complied  with  national, 
provincial, and local environmental requirements and maintained ISO 14001-2004 certification.  
 
34. 
Subprojects are located at existing sites in suburban areas designated for industrial use, 
so land acquisition will be minimal. Hence, with respect to involuntary resettlement the project is 
category  B,  while  for  indigenous  peoples  the  project  is  category  C.  The  corporate  audit  found 
that  LJEP’s  due  diligence  is  limited  to  determining  whether  the  local  government  has 
possession  of  the  land  in  accordance  with  national  laws.  Audits  of  two  potential  subprojects 
found  that  compensation  implemented  by  the  local  government  complies  with  ADB‘s 
requirements.  
 
35. 
Other  social  dimensions.  LJEP upholds gender equality, provides equal benefits and 
training  opportunities  for  all  staff  members,  and  strictly  follows  national  labor  laws  and 
regulations..  LJEP  will  comply  with  ADB’s  Social  Protection  Strategy19 and  report  regularly  to 
ADB  on  compliance—including that  of  its  contractors—with  national  labor  laws  consistent  with 
internationally recognized core labor standards.  

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
39. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
CNY600,000,000  (or  its  equivalent  in  US  dollars)  to  the  Longjiang  Environmental  Protection 
Group  Share  Company  Limited  for  the  Songhua  River  Basin  Water  Pollution  Control  and 
Management  Project  Private  Sector  Facility,  Phase  2  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  from 
ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.
